However , it 's not uncommon for some people to want to be recognized for more than just their given value . Jacks , nines , threes , Kings ... it 's all just to keep things nice and simple . Your card is your life . Whether you like it or not . <newline> <newline> `` Here we are ... Room 312 , up on the third floor . Here 's your pass , and I hope all goes well . '' <newline> <newline> He hastily takes the pass from her , giving her a socially required nod of approval , while a sense of disapproval still lingers about him . Stamping away towards the elevator , his hands and fingers fiddle over his lap in a shoddy attempt to keep himself calm once he stepped inside the metal box . All he received was one phone call . One call telling him he needed to be there . Of course , for an expecting father , that 's all the notice one needs , but a bit more detail would have not gone unappreciated . <newline> <newline> `` C'mon ... C'mon , c'mon ... Jesus , why is this thing so slow ? '' <newline> <newline> A small elderly woman taps him on the shoulder . Her face is kind and genuine , and her voice is shaky yet soft . <newline> <newline> `` In a hurry , young man ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Uh , yes . Yes , actually . My wife is expecting soon . '' <newline> <newline> `` Oh , is that so ? Congratulations ! What 's her card ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Well , thank you . It 's a Queen . Queen of Spades . '' <newline> <newline> `` That 's a lovely card ... Not many women have that suit . Y'know , I , myself , have a black suit . Clubs . Four of Clubs ! '' <newline> <newline> Although it 's such a low ranking , she gives the impression that she 's happy to have it , maybe even proud . And Jacks talking to Fours ... that 's not something that happens often . He almost does n't know what to say ... <newline> <newline> `` I- ... I 'm so- '' <newline> <newline> `` If you 're marrying a Queen , you must be up there yourself , eh ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Well , I gue- '' <newline> <newline> `` Y'know , I have a grandson in here , only about 7 years old right now . They gave him a Three of Diamonds ... Is n't that terrible ? '' <newline> <newline> `` ... Yea . It is . '' <newline> <newline> `` What 's your name ? You must have a lot of money lying around , right ? '' <newline> <newline> `` I 'm really sorry , uh , t-this is my floor . I really have to go . '' <newline> <newline> `` Where are you going ? ! Hey ! '' <newline> <newline> He manages to slip through the elevator doors on the third floor . The old lady does n't seem to be too happy anymore . <newline> <newline> `` M-My grandson is in Room 421 ! You 'll visit right ? ! '' <newline> <newline> He extends a reassuring hand , visible through the small , closing crack in the elevator doors , giving with it a false promise in their last , brief moment of eye contact . Another sigh leaves his lips as he regains his composure , his face pointed downwards with disappointment , his teeth clenching silently . <newline> <newline> `` Shit ... '' he whispers to himself , `` Always the goddamn cards ... '' <newline> <newline> He soon finds the room , and , for a brief moment , he sees his wife holding his infant son through the glass pane . A smile forms on his face , and his eyes even start to water . He reaches out for the doorknob when he notices a doctor holding his son 's card , about to give it to his wife . Instantly , he freezes . The door opens on its own . <newline> <newline> `` Mr. Stewart ? Your son is here . Are n't you going to go in ? '' <newline> <newline> `` ... Y ... Yes , thank you doctor . I will . In just a moment . '' <newline> <newline> `` ... What 's the matter , sir ? '' <newline> <newline> The smile returns , faded but still present , his eyes still glued to his infant son . <newline> <newline> `` I just do n't want to know yet . His card I mean . I just want to see him as he is . Even if it 's just for a minute . '' <newline> <newline> The doctor glances once at the son and then back at the father . He nods in agreement and closes the door behind him as Johnathan continues to look through the glass with endearment . <newline> <newline> After a short while , he opens the door himself . <newline>

prompt: When anyone is born , they are given a playing card from a standard deck , and it determines their place in society .
story:
In the city of Cartomancy, the air was alive with the soft rustle of suits and the whispered secrets of the deck. Every time a child was born, a playing card was drawn, and with it, their fate was sealed. The card would determine their place in society, their occupation, and even their destiny.

Aria was born on a sweltering summer day, and as she took her first breath, a Three of Clubs fluttered into her life. Her parents, overjoyed, gazed at the card in wonder. The Three of Clubs was a card of stability and hard work, a sign that Aria would grow up to be a diligent and responsible individual. She would be a clerk, a number-cruncher, and a master of the mundane.

As she grew, Aria's life unfolded with the predictability of a well-ordered deck. She attended school, learned her numbers, and mastered the art of filing. Her parents beamed with pride as she graduated at the top of her class, her Three of Clubs card a constant reminder of her potential.

But Aria's life was not without its challenges. She longed to break free from the monotony of her assigned role, to explore the world beyond the confines of her desk. She felt a restlessness, a sense of discontent that gnawed at her like a rabbit in a cage. Her parents, though well-meaning, couldn't understand her yearning for something more.

One day, while rummaging through her mother's old trunk, Aria stumbled upon a tattered deck of cards. The cards were unlike any she had ever seen before – they were worn, and the suits were mismatched, the numbers jumbled. As she flipped through the deck, a King of Spades caught her eye. It was a card of passion and creativity, a sign that Aria was meant for something more.

Aria's heart skipped a beat as she gazed at the card. She felt a spark of rebellion ignite within her, a desire to shatter the expectations of her Three of Clubs destiny. She began to sneak away from her desk, to explore the city and discover the secrets of the deck. She met a group of rebels, a motley crew of individuals who had also been dealt unexpected cards. There was Jax, the Eight of Diamonds, a free spirit with a heart full of adventure. There was Luna, the Queen of Hearts, a dreamer with a passion for art. And there was Kael, the Jack of Spades, a wild card with a penchant for chaos.

Together, they formed a secret society, a group of misfits who defied the conventions of Cartomancy. They danced in the streets, their cards a symbol of their defiance. They painted masterpieces, their art a reflection of their inner turmoil. And they laughed, their joy a beacon of hope in a world that often seemed too rigid.

Aria's life was no longer a predictable deck of cards. It was a wild, unpredictable ride, full of twists and turns. She had discovered a new suit, a new way of living. And as she looked at the King of Spades, now her constant companion, she knew that she would never be bound by the expectations of her Three of Clubs destiny.

prompt: A toy boat floats out to sea and has an adventure .
story: Possible Feels below : <newline> <newline> It was my twelfth birthday when I unwrapped a glorious model boat . It was two and a half feet long and shaped like a pirate ship . It had two sturdy masts which could be outfitted with black sails painted with my very own custom rendition of the jolly roger . I had been begging my Dad to teach me more about how to use his woodworking tools , so he bought this ship . He figured we could build it together , and it would let him show me how to use some of the tools . I remember the first time we set out to float in the pond near our house , my Dad looked so proud as I excitedly pushed it out into the water to watch it float in the wind . Building that boat was the closest we had ever been . <newline> <newline> It was two years later when my Dad was diagnosed with lung cancer and hospitalized . It was a long battle , and you could see he was in pain all the time . I do n't know what made me do it , but one day I went into his workshop and I just started building . I made little carvings , a few engravings , little things mostly , and I brought them to my Dad . They made him grin from ear to ear . So I just kept building ; and I got better . It felt like the only thing I could do to help , and I did n't know if it really did anything , but if it could make him happy for just a minute then I was going to do it . <newline> <newline> After a long 18 months my father passed away in his sleep . After his body was cremated my Mom was unsure what to do with the ashes , she felt like he deserved something special . My sister suggested spreading them around some of his favorite places , and it was my idea to put a few on the boat and let it take sail . So I placed a small glass jar with my Dad 's remains on our boat . And I wrote a note to explain how he always wanted to sail out into the world . Then one morning we went to the pier and pushed it out into the calm morning ocean . I did n't ever expect it to go anywhere , it was really more symbolic than anything . <newline> <newline> Now suddenly , here I was , running on the beach one Saturday morning years later and a thousand miles or so South of where I grew up when something caught my eye . I slowed down and made my way over the the rocks at the edge of the water . There was no way that crashed up against the rocks was my boat , my pirate ship . But unlikely as it seemed , I was certain this was the boat I felt with my Dad . I picked it up and carried it away from the water , then sat down on the beach to inspect it . The flags looked like they had been torn and sewn together at least seven times . The hull was full of cracks which had been fixed with wood putty . It looked like the boat had been shipwrecked multiple times and fixed up every time before being sent back out to the ocean . As I looked over it I realized the cabins at the back had been lined with something on the inside . <newline> <newline> I turned the boat and found a latch at the back of the boat . I opened the old ship to find the middle of the boat had been modified . It was cored out for easier access and lined with some sort of water proof material.The hull was filled with scraps of paper and small trinkets : sea shells , coins , a locket , small things . As I pulled out the papers I realized they were all numbered in the top left corner . <newline> <newline> First I found number one . It was my original letter explaining that I had built the boat with my Dad and sent his ashes out for one last journey . Then I found letter number two . It explained how a sister and brother found the boat one day . They had fixed the mast and sewn the sail back together before outlining instructions for future finders of the boat to fix it up , add something small , and set it out to sail . They had added sea shells from their collection . Note number seven was a teacher who brought it into his high school woodworking class . It was there were a student suggested they gut the boat and line the insides . This way more trinkets could fit and the letters would be safe without having to be placed in small bottles or plastic sandwich bags . <newline> <newline> Every letter had a story of the finders . They had fixed the boat , sewn the sails back together , written a not , and added a trinket before sending it back off . As I fought off the tears reading the letters I could only imagine how overjoyed my father would be to see our little woodworking project now . When I brought the boat home my daughter asked if it was for her . I told her not quite , but it would sure make me happy if she would help me fix it . She was seven years old , and I loved to spend every moment I could with her . <newline> <newline> It took us three weeks to fix the boat before we went out to the shore to set it out once more . My daughter had written her very own note explaining how we found the boat and why the next person who found it should help fix the boat again . She had added a few pieces of sea glass that she had found during our walks on the beach . Just before we set it off I placed her letter in the back off the boat . Lastly I placed in the small vile of my Dad 's ashes , and next to it I placed another small vile with my mother 's . Finally the two could be together again as they set off to explore the world .

prompt: A toy boat floats out to sea and has an adventure .
story:
The toy boat bobbed on the waves, its bright red hull a stark contrast to the dull grey of the ocean. It had been left behind on the beach, forgotten in the chaos of a summer's day. But as the tide pulled out, the boat found itself swept away, carried out to sea by the relentless current.

At first, it was a lonely journey, the boat drifting aimlessly on the waves. But as the sun began to set, casting a warm orange glow over the water, the boat felt a strange sense of excitement. It was as if it had been waiting for this moment, this chance to break free from its mundane existence.

As the stars began to twinkle in the night sky, the boat found itself in the midst of a school of bioluminescent fish. Their ethereal glow illuminated the water, casting an otherworldly light over the boat. It felt as though it was sailing through a dream, the fish darting and weaving around it like a shimmering curtain.

The boat continued on its journey, the fish leading the way. It passed through a coral reef, the vibrant colors of the sea anemones and coral a stark contrast to the dull grey of the ocean. The boat felt a sense of wonder, as if it was discovering a whole new world.

As the days passed, the boat found itself in the midst of a storm. The winds howled and the waves crashed against it, threatening to capsize it. But the boat held firm, its small wooden hull creaking and groaning under the pressure. It was a tiny, insignificant thing, but it refused to give up.

And then, just as suddenly as it had begun, the storm passed. The sun broke through the clouds, casting a warm, golden light over the water. The boat felt a sense of relief, as if it had been given a second chance.

As it continued on its journey, the boat found itself in the presence of a giant whale. The whale's massive body undulated through the water, its voice a low, rumbling growl. The boat felt a sense of awe, as if it was in the presence of a god.

But the whale was not a monster, nor was it a creature of myth. It was simply a creature, a being of the sea, living its life in the depths of the ocean. The boat felt a sense of connection, as if it had been given a glimpse into a world beyond its own.

And so the boat continued on its journey, a tiny, insignificant thing in a vast and mysterious universe. But it was no longer alone, for it had discovered a world of wonder and magic, a world that lay just beneath the surface of the ocean.

As the days turned into weeks, the boat found itself returning to the shore, its journey complete. But it was not the same boat that had been left behind. It had been changed by its adventure, its small wooden hull bearing the scars of its journey. It had discovered a world of wonder, and it would never be the same again.

The boat came to rest on the beach, its bright red hull a stark contrast to the dull grey of the shore. But it was no longer just a toy, nor was it just a piece of wood. It was a traveler, a wanderer, a being of the sea. And as it sat there, its wooden hull weathered and worn, it knew that it would never be content to simply sit on the beach again.

prompt: 9 out of 10 dentists recommend Drexco® brand toothpaste . What does the 10th dentist know , that he 's not telling us .
story: <newline> '' Lori ... cancel my next appointment , would you ? '' I tried to breathe deeply , and slowly , as I backed up a bit from the chair , as well as the man in it . Delorez was sitting in her office chair , speaking with whom I could only assume was our sales representative . <newline> <newline> `` Would you mind terribly if I had you hold for a moment ? '' She asked , as she saw the look of shock on my face droop even lower to disgust and fear . She clicked the landline to a hold , and adjusted her seat to face me , concern forming a crease between her brows . <newline> <newline> `` What 's wrong ? '' She had known me for years , so she could clearly tell something was up . <newline> '' H-his teeth ... '' I stammered . For the first time in years , I was utterly dumbfounded . <newline> `` They 're so ... soft . '' I gagged , as I acknowledged the texture of the patients teeth . Lori just stared at me , not realizing the gravity of the situation . <newline> <newline> I moved forward again to the sleeping patients side , hoping beyond reason I had imagined it all . As I gingerly placed my instrument along the side teeth of his mouth , once again they slightly gave way , caving inward towards his throat . The texture was organic , though almost fungal in nature . Blood droplets sprouted in the raw spaces , left by the the easily manipulated teeth . `` This man was patient 33 in the lab study , correct ? '' <newline> <newline> Blood began to pool at the back of his throat , so I quickly ducked to find the suction mechanism , ashamed for allowing myself to become so dangerously distracted . As soon as it was in my hand , I looked up to see where to place the end of the instrument , only to be faced with a small pooling of maggots , where I had only just seen the blood . This lead me to dry heave . One by one , they burst into enormous black flies , which rose above my head , buzzing and dancing to some unknown beat . Suddenly , the unconscious man lunged toward me , clamping his mouth over my shocked agape lower jaw , and biting down with enough force to burst his softened teeth in my own mouth . <newline> <newline> Finally regaining my wits as I heaved and choked on the viscous liquid that had excreted from his softened teeth , I shoved him to the table , and jammed the suction instrument into my open mouth as I held him down . I looked back to the desk Delorez was sitting at , and I was n't shocked to find her hovering over the trashcan . A look of pure terror etched into her features . <newline> <newline> `` That 's ... that is n't from the Drexco trial is it ? ? ? '' She asked . Still in a small amount of shock . She had also been a member in the trial , though I knew she had received the placebo paste . I wreched and spit , and could barely nod before looking back to patient 33 . <newline> <newline> An electric blue and white ( same as the toothpaste ) but stringy substance pushed out of the patients gums and teeth . Branching , pulsating , and almost knocking me over . These tendrils wound themselves around my upper arms , and even as I broke free of them , stumbling backwards , more would sprout . <newline> <newline> As the tendrils burst from the force of my hands tearing them away , a yellow powder dusted the air , suddenly making it very difficult to breath . At this , the only person left standing was myself . Lori had somehow collapsed in a fit of giggles , with the patient still out , even as I fought back my own laughter . I picked up the receiver , clicking the held line . Something is very wrong . <newline> <newline> `` Subject 33 is showing serious symptoms of negative response to the toothpaste trial ! '' I practically shouted , trying to keep my wits about me . `` Do not proceed with endorsement under *any* circumstances ! '' <newline> <newline> I should have said more . I wish I would have been able to , before folding to the floor in hysterics . It wasnt till the next day , P33 had finally opened his eyes at around 5 am , after being transferred to an ER , though he ca n't seem to open his mouth again . The first ad for Drexco toothpaste was aired even as I admitted myself to the hospital . No matter how slim the chance of getting these negative side effects , it isnt worth the spreading of this disease . Constant fits of laughter were concerning enough alone , but my teeth suddenly ache ... And I could swear they are getting softer . <newline> <newline> Edit : most credit to u/iia for managing to inspire me to try to write something . Hopefully I do them more justice in the future : )

prompt: 9 out of 10 dentists recommend Drexco® brand toothpaste . What does the 10th dentist know , that he 's not telling us .
story:
Dr. Kaida's hands moved with a practiced ease, the soft bristles of his dental mirror gliding across the patient's teeth with a soothing rhythm. His eyes, a deep, piercing brown, locked onto the patient's, and for a moment, the world outside receded. This was what he lived for – the quiet intimacy of the dental chair, the gentle give of a patient's gums, the soft whisper of a smile.

But Dr. Kaida's thoughts were elsewhere. He was a man consumed by a secret, one that had been eating away at him for years. It started with a phone call, a whispered conversation with a colleague who had stumbled upon something disturbing. Drexco, the brand of toothpaste that dominated the market, was not what it seemed.

At first, Dr. Kaida had dismissed the rumors as mere gossip, the ramblings of a disgruntled employee. But as he delved deeper, he discovered a trail of disturbing evidence. Patients who had used Drexco toothpaste for years reported strange side effects – headaches, dizziness, even vivid nightmares. And then there were the ingredients, a cocktail of chemicals that seemed to defy explanation.

Dr. Kaida's mind reeled as he pieced together the puzzle. He had always prided himself on his integrity, his commitment to his patients' health and well-being. But what if he had been complicit in a cover-up? What if he had been recommending Drexco toothpaste to his patients, without knowing the full extent of its dangers?

As he finished the patient's cleaning and sent them on their way, Dr. Kaida felt a sense of unease settle in the pit of his stomach. He couldn't shake the feeling that he was living a lie, that every smile he had helped to create was tainted by the secrets he kept.

The office was quiet, the only sound the soft hum of the dental equipment. Dr. Kaida's eyes wandered to the shelf in the corner, where the Drexco toothpaste sat, its bright blue and white packaging a beacon of normalcy. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he realized that he was the only one who knew the truth.

The phone on his desk rang, shrill and insistent. Dr. Kaida's heart skipped a beat as he picked it up, his voice steady. "Drexco Dental, Dr. Kaida speaking." The voice on the other end was familiar, a colleague from the dental association. "Dr. Kaida, we need to talk."

Dr. Kaida's mind was racing, his thoughts a jumbled mess of fear and doubt. He knew that he couldn't keep the secret forever, that eventually, the truth would come to light. But for now, he was trapped, bound by a web of deceit and silence.

As he hung up the phone, Dr. Kaida felt a sense of resignation wash over him. He knew that he had to make a choice, to either come clean or keep the secret buried. But as he looked at the Drexco toothpaste, he couldn't shake the feeling that he was staring into the abyss, with no safety net to catch him if he fell.

prompt: After almost 1,000 years the population of a generation ship has lost the ability to understand most technology and now lives at a preindustrial level . Today the ship reaches its destination and the automated systems come back online .
story: Every day is the same . Wake up , gather materials for cooking and place it on the heat stone . <newline> <newline> This one has been in my family for years . We 're proud of it because it can be moved . <newline> <newline> That 's why my grand mother is the head of our village . She inherited the heat stone so she 's the He-Kith . It is also our scribestone . <newline> <newline> One day I 'll be the He-kith so I have to learn the stories . The writing . The history . <newline> <newline> Our scribestone requires that I know how to engrave the stories . And every day it 's empty ready for new ones . <newline> <newline> My favorite part of the year is the retelling . When the He-kith touches the scribestone and we can see the old stories as if they had just been engraved . <newline> <newline> It 's time for the retelling and she touches the stone and our Ka-ette are gathered around to see the stories of this last year and for them to be retold . I listen raptly but also watch every little detail knowing that I will have to do this one day too . And then my children . And their children . <newline> <newline> Each day appears on the scribestone with a rumble and the stone receding to show the new engravings . <newline> <newline> Our first day of this year . After the harvest . And what we harvested and what we will plant . We find that if we do n't scribe in what we will plant we have a drier year . We always write what we will plant . Failure means some may die from hunger . <newline> <newline> The day of the festival of stars where we engrave the stars above us on the scribestone . We always know when it 's time because the scribestone turns black but has a blue glow . On that day we etch in the new stars , turn around and do it again . I do n't understand why we do this but so many of our traditions must be kept whether we know why or not . <newline> <newline> Here comes the etchings of life where we enter the names of those who are born and their Ka-hen and of course our Ka-ette , Ra . <newline> <newline> Now for the etchings of passing where we see the names of those who passed on . And their places of plantings . <newline> <newline> As we prepare for the next engraving there 's a shifting of the ground beneath us . And a loud screeching sound . <newline> <newline> The scribestone changes to a red color . I 've never seen that before and from the look of my He-Kith 's face neither has she . Panic sets in and many of our Ka-ette scramble to their feet and run to their homes . <newline> <newline> But not my He-Kith and so I too will stay . I 'm terrified . <newline> <newline> Above us the sky opens like it does during the festival of stars and the scribe stone turns black . My He-kith grabs the writing stone but her hand is shaking . She too is terrified . She etches in a star and the scribestone glows orange and turns flat . She tries again . Same thing . She calls to me and hands me the writing stone . <newline> <newline> I take it and slowly etch in the stars . And wait for it to flash but my hands must have been steadier because it sets in and the stone makes the whirring sound it does during the festival of stars . I repeat the process for the brightest stars as I had been taught and the stone turns gray . <newline> <newline> And then something new happens . The sky begins to paint circles over the stars and to draw lines and emblems on them . The were names . Names of our Ka-ette . And our neighboring Ka-ette . <newline> <newline> And next to each one is a emblem . The word for `` end of harvest '' . All except for the Kith-den . <newline> <newline> I wait for hours staring at the sky trying to make sense of what is happening when a young girl from the village of Kith-den runs up . Their He-Kith is dead . The fright from the sky and sound scared her so much that she died . And their successor ca n't be found . They searched but she must have run away . I do n't blame her . The thought crossed my mind . <newline> <newline> My He-Kith tells me that I must go to their village and complete the ritual of the festival of the stars . I do n't want to . I want to stay here with my mother and sisters . Or run to the fields to my father and brothers . But she insists . <newline> <newline> After much prodding and reminding me that she is too old to make such a journey I go with the young girl . <newline> <newline> As we approach her village I see their scribestone laying on the ground next to their He-kith who seemed as one who passed in their sleep . I pick it up but it does n't shift or change or make a sound . I do n't know what to do so I give up and lay it on their He-kith and as it touches her it turns black and I pick it up again . I quickly but carefully etch in the stars and as I do I see the sky paint Ka-den . <newline> <newline> Suddenly the sky turns black and then it becomes bright as day . And then in the sky we see a woman . She looks down on us and speaks . But it sounds odd . Like the words of old . I can make out most of it . She says we have reached the harvest home . The place of our final rest . Our journey is done . <newline> <newline> As she speaks we see a blue orb appear and she tells us that our `` boat ? '' has arrived at `` Err-arth '' . Home of homes . <newline> <newline> The scribestone then changes to a faint green and a single symbol etches on it . `` Plant '' I think it says . It looks like plant but it 's different . I circle the etching and the scribestone then shatters into dust throwing me back . And the sky changes to show Ka-den green and moving towards the blue orb in the sky . <newline> <newline> Shortly after I see Ka-ette , Ka-tul , Ka-ren and thousands of others in green and moving towards the blue orb . All except for one . `` Ka-mune '' . Theirs turns red and then fades away . And shortly after I see a white plume and a huge white/grey sphere fly away up the horizon followed by a huge flame . And then it 's gone . Into the stars . <newline> <newline> Then the great change . First the lake dried . Followed by the mountains which turned to dust just as the scribestone did . Then the houses in the village turned to dust leaving only the few inhabitants who had n't run away from the village but rather had huddled in their homes . Their belongings still there but the walls were just gone . <newline> <newline> The blue orb sets in the sky and we see a new orb . A bright whitish/yellow one . And a painted etching `` Fire source '' and then a light rumbling as the ground vibrates beneath my feet and the horizon glows a faint red . This glow is slowly replaced by a bluish colors and the stars fade away . I 've never seen a sky without stars before . But in their place is the `` Fire source '' . <newline> <newline> More rumbling and then the ground stops vibrating and then a loud whoosh and a bright flash . <newline> <newline> I huddle down in fear as I see the horizon change . There are new mountains . And a large lake where the old one used to be . And I hear a strange high pitched sound as a creature soars above me . <newline> <newline> I run back to where my village was and I find my He-kith and she looks at me with such joy and fear on her face . She puts her hand on me and hands me the etching stone and points to a opening in the nearby mountain . <newline> <newline> I run in and see a wall that looks like the scribestone and use my etching stone to write the story of what just happened . The words stay . But they do n't move . These are n't like our scribestone . Or the mountains of our home where the words could be read from generations before . These stay but ca n't be reused . <newline> <newline> I write and I write . Every day in our new home . I write what I see . What I hear . <newline> <newline> And most of all the stars . They do n't change during the festival of stars like they used to . They are the same . They move . But always come back . Just as Ka-mune circles Err-arth , perhaps watching over us ? <newline> <newline> Edit : typos and clarity a few plot holes .

prompt: After almost 1,000 years the population of a generation ship has lost the ability to understand most technology and now lives at a preindustrial level . Today the ship reaches its destination and the automated systems come back online .
story:
As the ship's hull creaked and groaned, the inhabitants of the vessel stirred from their slumber, blinking in the bright, artificial light that had been their only reality for nearly a millennium. The air was thick with the smell of old wood and stale air, a reminder of the countless generations that had lived and died within these metal walls. The once-majestic corridors now felt cramped and claustrophobic, the walls adorned with faded murals and dusty relics of a bygone era.

The ship's automated systems, once the backbone of their existence, had long since fallen silent. The inhabitants had grown accustomed to the gentle hum of manual labor, the soft clinking of tools, and the warm glow of candles and lanterns. They had forgotten the rush of electricity, the whir of machinery, and the soft beeps of computers. Their lives had become a slow, deliberate dance, with each step and gesture choreographed to the rhythms of nature.

But now, as the ship approached its destination, the automated systems stirred back to life. The air was filled with the sweet scent of ozone and the soft whir of machinery, a cacophony that was both exhilarating and terrifying. The inhabitants stumbled and staggered, their eyes wide with wonder as they struggled to comprehend the sudden return of the world they had thought they knew.

A young woman, her hair tied back in a simple knot, stumbled through the corridors, her hands outstretched as if to grasp the invisible threads of a forgotten reality. She passed by a group of men, their faces set in determined lines, as they struggled to comprehend the strange, glowing rectangles that had once been their windows to the world. They stared at the screens, their eyes wide with confusion, as the words and images danced before them like a madman's jest.

In the ship's great hall, a group of children gathered around a small, glowing box, their eyes wide with wonder as they watched the images of a world they had only heard of in stories. They laughed and pointed, their faces alight with excitement, as the box brought to life a world of color and sound that had been lost to them for so long.

As the ship's systems continued to awaken, the inhabitants began to realize the true extent of their loss. They had forgotten the world they had left behind, the world they had been sent to colonize. They had forgotten the feel of the sun on their skin, the taste of fresh air, and the sound of birds singing in the trees. They had forgotten the world, and with it, their own identities.

The young woman, her eyes still wide with wonder, stumbled upon a small, leather-bound book. She opened it, and the pages crackled with age, releasing a faint scent of parchment and ink. As she read the words, her eyes widened in shock, and she felt a sense of disorientation wash over her. She was no longer a member of a generation ship, no longer a child of the void. She was a person, a human being, with a past and a future that stretched out before her like an endless road.

As the ship's systems continued to awaken, the inhabitants began to realize that they had a choice to make. They could continue to live in the past, clinging to the familiar rhythms of their old lives. Or they could step into the unknown, embracing the uncertainty and wonder of a new world. The young woman, her eyes still shining with tears, made her decision. She took a deep breath, and stepped into the unknown, ready to face whatever lay ahead.

prompt: You 're the leader , and you keep trying to get your people to rebel , but they wo n't .
story: I sat alone in the shoddy conference room , contemplating what had just transpired minutes ago . I had met with the appointed officers of divisions one through ten . We spoke about the legitimacy of a rebellion ; whether or not each district could successfully mount a revolt and find themselves in command . Out of all ten divisions , only one -- division two , which happened to have the weakest armed government of all divisions -- confirmed that we had the go-ahead with the operation . <newline> <newline> `` None of you can ... win ? '' I queried carefully . <newline> <newline> There had been a lengthy pause between my asking of this and their answering . Quite a lot of glancing and stressed body movements passed among the officers during this pause . Finally , if not weakly for all the power division five 's leader held , he proclaimed to me this : `` Harold , we -- divisions one , and three through ten , do not feel that a revolt would be in the best interest of the parties we command . As it stands , the *people's* morale , '' -- this bit was emphasized in a truly odd fashion , suggesting something , although I was unsure of what at the time -- '' is strong enough to mount the suggested plan of attack . '' <newline> <newline> Their eyes fell upon me shakily , seemingly all at once . My head was pounding slightly , a headache or some anger overtaking my mind . <newline> <newline> *They 're ... every district outnumbers the elite ten to one . Damn ... they 're ... * I sigh loudly and long , and conceded to myself , *such is , as it is so ... * <newline> <newline> A trifle stricken towards lunacy at their suggestion to trash the last 10 month 's work , I carefully laid out my next dialogue . <newline> <newline> `` I understand your positions . I do very much understand , you know . Risking lives is not easy , especially so when those under your charge are not mentally or emotionally fit for battle . They have families , children to think for . They can not simply give everything for such a chance to receive nothing , and on what ? What have we offered them in true substance -- good faith ? That is of course a weak form of motivation . I hereby dismiss this meeting ; all who are present please find your way back to your district 's office , and know that my understanding rests comfortably with you . '' <newline> <newline> several of the officers appeared relieved . *Good* , I had thought . *That is what we need . If they become distressed , things can only get worse . * <newline> <newline> While all other officers appeared more relaxed than previously , district two 's officer , Simon , seemed to share my mood , though a great deal more outwardly . I had watched them file out of the room fairly neatly , on their way back to wherever the hell they were going to go . <newline> <newline> So now here I am , staring at the shitty oak wood table where the conference took place , in my shitty chair , in this shitty little shack on the outskirts of the Citadel . A light pattering of rain had began to sound from the windows that would n't let their grime be washed away , no matter how hard one scrubbed . It was obvious to me now after my internal deliberation that not only the people were afraid , but officers themselves were afraid -- not quite , I do not believe , of those in power , but rather about the institution it represents . They lived their whole lives under the careful tutelage and dictation of these district 's governments , what is a life without it to them ? When they look to the battle -- no , war -- that awaits them with my plan , what the hell do they see themselves gaining ? This is n't a damn movie , and when faced with losing your life or living as it is , the jury is out on which of these is more preferable . <newline> <newline> So then , how do I convince these tired and scared men to rally their district in support ? It is not obvious . Humans are complicated beings , but we are all humans . None of us want to do terrible things , and those who do lack the understanding that were they to sit on the other end of the gun they fire or the law they pass , it would be some new hell to live . But in that vein of precise goodness that I believe we all have is a drive to assist any in need however we see possible . Does a man pass a beggar on the street without dropping coin into his pockets , unless that man himself is a beggar ? <newline> <newline> Yes , this is how I must frame the proposal . My people do not fight for themselves , nor their families . In the grand scheme , none of them are important as individual entities . Rather , they fight for their friends and those of their society that wallow within the same slum . Battles would be won for the man by your side , and his family that sits aside yours . We should be warriors vested in the greater good of our society , not the greater good of our selves . <newline> <newline> As this wave of understanding washed over me , I took out my mobile telephone and dialed the number of my contact at the Citadel broadcasting station . A brief ring , and then : `` Hello ? What do you need , any developments ? '' <newline> <newline> I smile to myself , reveling in the genius of my discovery . `` Hannah , I need you to arrange me some time on air . I 've got a special message for my people . ''

prompt: You 're the leader , and you keep trying to get your people to rebel , but they wo n't .
story:
The city's streets were a canvas of worn, cracked sidewalks and faded advertisements, a testament to the desperation that seeped from every pore. I stood atop a crumbling water tower, the wind whipping my hair into a frenzy as I gazed out upon the sea of faces below. The crowd was a tapestry of hope and despair, each thread woven from the same fragile fabric of existence.

I raised my voice, my words carrying on the wind as I addressed the masses. "Rise up, my friends! Break free from the chains that bind you! We are the ones who have been silenced, who have been oppressed, who have been forced to live in the shadows of those who would seek to control us!"

But my words fell on deaf ears. The crowd's response was a collective shrug, a gentle rustling of leaves as they turned away from me. I watched, a pang of frustration twisting in my chest, as they dispersed into the crowded streets, each one lost in their own private world.

I descended from the water tower, my footsteps echoing off the buildings as I made my way through the throngs of people. I stopped at a street vendor, purchasing a steaming cup of coffee from the vendor's calloused hands. The aroma wafted up, a bitter reminder of the bitter reality that I faced.

As I sipped my coffee, I noticed a young girl, no more than ten years old, sitting on a bench, her eyes fixed on the ground. She was a tiny, insignificant speck in the vast sea of humanity, but there was something about her that drew me in. Perhaps it was the way her shoulders slumped, as if the weight of the world rested upon her small frame.

I sat down beside her, my presence a gentle disturbance in the stillness. "What's wrong, little one?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper.

She looked up at me, her eyes red-rimmed from crying. "I don't know what's wrong," she said, her voice a mere whisper. "I just feel... trapped. Like I'm stuck in a never-ending nightmare, with no escape."

I nodded, my heart aching with empathy. I knew that feeling all too well. "You're not alone," I said, my voice a gentle breeze on a summer's day. "We're all trapped, in our own way. But we can break free, if we choose to."

The girl looked up at me, a glimmer of hope in her eyes. For a moment, I thought I saw a spark of rebellion ignite within her, a flame that could grow into a wildfire. But it was just a flicker, a brief, shining moment of defiance.

As the sun dipped below the horizon, casting the city in a warm, golden light, I knew that I had failed. Again. The crowd dispersed, the city's inhabitants returning to their daily routines, oblivious to the call to arms that I had raised.

I stood up, my eyes scanning the sea of faces, searching for that one person, that one spark of resistance. But it was gone, lost in the crowd, leaving me with nothing but the bitter taste of defeat.

prompt: The Statues
story:
In the city's forgotten quarter, where crumbling facades seemed to lean in, as if sharing a secret, the statues stood watch. Their stone eyes, once bright with life, now gazed out upon the world with a dull, glassy sheen, as if the very soul had been drained from their marble hearts.

The air was heavy with the scent of damp earth and decay, a morbid perfume that clung to the skin like a shroud. It was a place where time had lost all meaning, where the passage of seasons was marked only by the slow creep of ivy up crumbling walls and the faint, eerie glow of luminescent mushrooms that sprouted from the cracks in the pavement.

Amidst this desolate landscape, a young woman named Lena wandered, her footsteps echoing off the walls as she navigated the narrow alleys. Her eyes, a deep, rich brown, seemed to drink in the beauty of the forgotten quarter, as if she saw in its decay a reflection of her own fractured soul.

As she turned a corner, a figure caught her eye - a statue of a woman, her face serene, her arms outstretched as if embracing the world. But it was the statue's eyes that drew Lena in, their glassy sheen seeming to hold a secret, a message that only she could decipher.

Lena felt an inexplicable pull towards the statue, as if the woman's gaze was beckoning her closer. She reached out a hand, hesitated, and then touched the statue's stone cheek. The moment her skin made contact, the world around her seemed to shift, the colors deepening, the air thickening with an almost palpable sense of longing.

The statue's eyes, once dull, now flared to life, their depths burning with a fierce, inner light. Lena felt herself being drawn into their depths, as if she was being pulled into a world of memories, of secrets, of stories that only the statue knew.

As she stood there, transfixed, the statue began to speak, its voice a low, husky whisper that seemed to come from the very marrow of its bones. "I was once a dancer," it said, "a woman of the night, with feet that barely touched the ground and a heart that sang with the music of the city."

Lena felt herself being transported to a world of smoke and mirrors, of jazz clubs and speakeasies, of secret trysts and stolen kisses. The statue's eyes seemed to hold a thousand stories, each one a thread in a tapestry of love and loss, of joy and heartache.

As the statue's words faded away, Lena felt herself being pulled back into the present, the world around her seeming to shift and blur. She looked down at her hand, still touching the statue's cheek, and saw that her fingers were stained with a faint, pinkish hue, as if the statue's blood had seeped into her skin.

In that moment, Lena knew that she had been changed, that the statue's secrets had been imparted to her, and that she would never see the world in the same way again. The statues, once mere monuments to a bygone era, now seemed to hold a power, a magic that only revealed itself to those who dared to listen.

prompt: All injuries , emotional or physical , are displayed on a person in the form of a scar . You come across a man covered head to toe in disfiguring marks , speaking with a woman who bears only a single scar .
story: The old man ’ s beard was the most magnificent thing about him . <newline> <newline> The rest of him was painful to even look at . Thick ropes of scar tissue bloomed pink and silver over every patch of skin . His fingers curled into stiff claws , all swollen knuckles and small , sunken nails . He blinked every so often , heavy lids seeming to take an age to travel across clouded eyes . His beard , yellow and old at the tips , was thick and healthy where it grew from his jowls , hinting at whatever hidden vitality still inside him . He sat still upon the cold stone bench in the park . Back hunched , feet planted solidly amongst rasping autumn leaves . And he smiled . Despite the scars flaring to angry red as his skin stretched , he smiled with infinite patience at the woman sitting opposite him . <newline> <newline> Oh , the woman , the beautiful woman with raven hair and fierce haughty eyes . Skin smooth as velvet save the single scar upon her chest , the ridged line that ran from her collarbone into the cleavage of her immodest dress . She met the old man ’ s gaze , glared back with annoyance and defiance . <newline> <newline> “ I don ’ t know why you even bother coming here anymore , ” she uttered , words tense as a coiled snake . <newline> <newline> The old man laughed . He stroked the scraggly tip of his snowy beard , a rigid and awkward motion . “ It is not a chore , my child . I enjoy my visits . Even if those I visit may not feel the same. ” <newline> <newline> She scoffed , crossing her arms half in derision , half from the chill . “ Don ’ t know why you bother , ” she repeated sullenly . “ You realise that the more you see , the worse it gets , right ? ” <newline> <newline> A slow , sage nod in reply , neutral and thoughtful and silent . <newline> <newline> “ Especially here , talking with me , ” the woman continued , eyes narrowing into slits as she regarded the old man suspiciously . “ I know how you feel . How you wish I ’ d been more like my brothers . How you hate me for opening your eyes to the fact that things could go wrong . Every time you look at me , another little scar appears. ” She paused , smirking , gaze flicking up and down his stooped frame . “ Not that it makes much difference overall. ” <newline> <newline> “ I do not hate you , ” the man said kindly . His smile faded somewhat , and his stare wandered to the half-bare trees around them . “ Although , yes , it does hurt. ” <newline> <newline> The woman seemed to take joy in his quiet admission . She grinned sharply . “ It ’ s your own fault . *I* don ’ t hurt. ” It was true ; she was far too proud to . Her world was perfect . Her choices , her challenges , her creations—everything held in her grasp too securely to ever wound her . She had power and she had freedom and she had *distance* , and those were the shields against all that she faced . Unlike the old man , who let every little suffering bother him to the core . See a dead kitten and he would scar over . It disgusted her . <newline> <newline> “ One day , ” the old man replied with gentle certainty , “ you will wish you did. ” <newline> <newline> The woman only sighed , rolling her eyes . “ Talking to you is so *tedious* . Seriously , take a leaf from my book and stop bothering . You care far too much , and look what that ’ s doing to you . And worse—nobody even gives a shit . How many people have talked to you today ? How many have even stomached to *look* at you ? ” <newline> <newline> “ You have. ” He smiled that same serene smile , mindless of his tight scars . <newline> <newline> The woman stood up fluidly and bent down in a mock bow . “ Not anymore . I have better things to do . Until next time , unless you finally come to your senses and give up on these stupid useless pilgrimages. ” <newline> <newline> She turned and strode away , ending the conversation abruptly . As she walked , leaves crunching under snakeskin boots , she felt the ancient scar on her chest twinge with the faintest spark of pain . The wind howled . Its cold embrace brought to her a small whisper . “ *I will stop when you start . * ” <newline> <newline> The woman glanced back . The scarred old man was gone , leaving only a small pile of dried leaves , fluttering against the bench like moth wings and aimless ghosts .

prompt: All injuries , emotional or physical , are displayed on a person in the form of a scar . You come across a man covered head to toe in disfiguring marks , speaking with a woman who bears only a single scar .
story:
The streets were a tapestry of stories, each thread a testament to the intricate weave of human experience. I navigated the crowded alleys, weaving past vendors and pedestrians, until I stumbled upon a small, unassuming café. The sign above the door read "The Marked", and I felt an inexplicable pull, as if the very fabric of the city was urging me to enter.

Inside, the air was thick with the scent of old books and stale coffee. I spotted a man sitting at a corner table, his face a topography of scars. His arms, legs, and torso were a labyrinth of twisted, raised marks, each one a topographic map of its own unique history. His eyes, however, were the only unscarred feature, two bright, piercing orbs that seemed to bore into my very soul.

He was speaking with a woman, her face a single, delicate scar above her left eyebrow. Her eyes sparkled with a quiet intensity, and her voice was like a gentle breeze on a summer's day. I felt a pang of curiosity, and my feet seemed to move of their own accord, carrying me towards the table.

As I approached, the man looked up, his eyes locking onto mine with an unnerving intensity. I felt a shiver run down my spine, but the woman's gaze was like a warm hug, enveloping me in a sense of calm. She smiled, and I felt my own lips curve upwards in response.

"Mind if I join you?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper.

The man's gaze never wavered, but he nodded, his eyes never leaving mine. The woman, however, smiled and patted the empty chair beside her.

"I'm Kael," the man said, his voice low and gravelly. "And this is Aria."

"Aria, this is...I don't know, I didn't catch your name," I stammered, feeling a little like a trespasser in their private world.

"Aria," she repeated, her eyes sparkling with amusement. "And you are...?"

I hesitated, unsure of how to respond. The man's gaze seemed to bore into my very soul, as if searching for some hidden truth. But Aria's smile was like a balm, soothing my frazzled nerves.

"I'm just a passerby," I said finally, feeling a little embarrassed. "I stumbled upon this place, and...I don't know, it felt like I was meant to be here."

Kael's gaze never wavered, but I sensed a flicker of interest behind his eyes. Aria, however, leaned in, her voice taking on a conspiratorial tone.

"You see, we're not just people with scars," she said, her eyes glinting with mischief. "We're a map, a topography of our experiences. Every mark, every scar, tells a story. And we're not just talking about physical wounds."

Kael's gaze snapped to hers, and for a moment, I thought I saw a flash of anger. But then, his expression softened, and he nodded.

"Emotional scars are just as real," he said, his voice low and husky. "And we wear them on our sleeves, or rather, on our skin."

I felt a shiver run down my spine as I realized the truth in their words. Every person I had ever met, every stranger I had ever encountered, was a map of their own unique experiences. And in that moment, I felt a deep sense of connection to this man and woman, to the intricate tapestry of human experience that bound us all together.

As I sat there, surrounded by the intricate topography of Kael's scars, I felt a sense of peace wash over me. It was as if I had finally found a place where I belonged, a place where my own scars could be seen, and understood.

I nodded knowingly as my brains began to slide out my ears – I silently prayed for the first time in ten years , mentally urging them to hurry up and look away so that I could dump the damn cup into one of their drinks . I retreated to my happy place as they enthusiastically debated with each other . I absentmindedly took a drink from my cup . <newline> <newline> The roar of thousands of people blew out my ears as I frantically searched for the spirit animal that had been dry humping my soul for the past six hours . Angels and demons danced around a multihued sky , as cardinals Azikiwe and Ortega jabbered something about the first unanimous papal selection in Catholic history . <newline> <newline> “ Shit , that sounds important ” , I thought to myself , and tried to find my notebook , my pen , or at least a napkin to write that down on . prompt: After a series of misunderstandings and miscommunications you find yourself Pope of the Catholic Church
story:
I stood before the ornate mirror in my small, cluttered apartment, adjusting the rumpled collar of my worn cassock. The morning light streaming through the grimy window highlighted the faint smudges of last night's pizza sauce on my shirt. I couldn't help but chuckle at the absurdity of it all. Who would have thought that a chance encounter with a group of enthusiastic protesters at a local coffee shop would lead me to this moment?

It started innocently enough. I was sipping on a cappuccino, lost in thought, when a group of zealous Catholics burst into the shop, brandishing signs and shouting slogans. I, being the curious type, decided to intervene, attempting to reason with them. But, in the heat of the moment, I inadvertently grabbed the wrong megaphone, and my words were misinterpreted as a call to arms. The next thing I knew, I was being whisked away by a team of frantic PR handlers, who whisked me off to a hastily arranged press conference.

Before I could even process what was happening, I was being thrust into the spotlight, forced to defend the Church's stance on a contentious issue. My words, though well-intentioned, only seemed to fuel the fire, and soon I was being vilified by the very people I had tried to help. The media frenzy surrounding my "gaffe" was relentless, and I found myself at the center of a maelstrom, with the entire Catholic hierarchy breathing down my neck.

And then, in a bizarre twist of fate, the Pope himself called me into his chambers. I was ushered into a dimly lit room, the air thick with the scent of old leather and pipe smoke. The Pope, a man I had admired from afar, looked at me with a piercing gaze, his eyes seeming to bore into my very soul.

"You, my son," he said, his voice low and gravelly, "are the only one who can bring balance to this chaotic world. You have a unique gift, a gift of compassion and understanding. I want you to be my successor."

I was stunned. Me? The Pope? It was a joke, a cruel prank played on a hapless coffee shop regular. But as I looked into the Pope's eyes, I saw something there, a spark of recognition, a glimmer of hope.

I accepted the role, and before I knew it, I was standing in the Sistine Chapel, surrounded by the weight of history and tradition. The Cardinals, resplendent in their finery, looked at me with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion. I, on the other hand, felt like a fish out of water, a man out of time.

As I took the oath of office, I couldn't help but think of the protesters, the media, and the countless others who had contributed to this moment. I knew that I had a long and difficult road ahead of me, but I was determined to use this unexpected opportunity to bring people together, to find common ground in a world that seemed to be tearing itself apart.

The Pope's words echoed in my mind as I looked out at the sea of faces before me: "The Church is not just a institution, it's a community. And you, my son, are the key to unlocking its true potential." I smiled, feeling a sense of purpose wash over me. I was ready to take on the challenge, to be the Pope that the world needed.

prompt: As we stood there , staring up at the moon , a giant crack appeared . So big , it was visible to the naked eye .
story:
We stood there, our feet rooted to the spot, as if the very earth itself had been frozen in time. The moon, a silver crescent hovering above the treetops, seemed to mock us with its serene beauty. The night air was heavy with the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves, a primordial aroma that stirred something deep within us.

I gazed up at the moon, my eyes tracing the gentle curve of its face. The craters, like ancient scars, told the story of eons past, of collisions and catastrophes that had shaped the very fabric of our universe. And then, without warning, the moon's surface began to shift. A giant crack, a fissure of impossible proportions, stretched across its face like a gash in the skin of the night.

The crack was so vast, so monumental, that it seemed to defy the laws of nature. It was as if the moon itself had been rent asunder, its very essence torn free from the gravitational hold of the earth. The sound that followed was like thunder, a low, rumbling growl that vibrated through every cell in my body.

As we stood there, transfixed by the spectacle, the crack began to glow. A soft, ethereal light, like the first whispers of dawn, seeped from the fissure and spread across the sky. The light was mesmerizing, drawing us in with an otherworldly allure. I felt myself being pulled towards the crack, as if by an unseen force, my feet moving of their own accord.

My companion, a girl with skin as pale as the moon, reached out a trembling hand. Her fingers brushed against mine, and I felt a jolt of electricity run through my body. We stood there, our hands clasped, as the crack continued to glow. The light enveloped us, a warm, golden radiance that seemed to seep into our very souls.

And then, in an instant, the light vanished. The crack was gone, the moon restored to its former, serene beauty. The night air was silent once more, the only sound the soft crunch of underbrush beneath our feet. We stood there, frozen, our hands still clasped, as if we had been a part of something much greater than ourselves.

As we slowly released each other, I felt a sense of disorientation, as if I had been living in a dream world. The girl's eyes, still shining with a soft, lunar light, met mine, and I knew that we had shared something profound, something that would stay with us forever. The moon, once again, hung in the sky, a serene and beautiful presence, but I knew that I would never look at it in the same way again.
